brief: Community events focussed on health promotion
name: Community events focussed on health promotion including recreational activities and health challenges
Sporting groups and participation

brief: After-school activities and groups for youths
name: After-school activities and groups for youths, run by peers/advocates
Increase connections within and across community organizations and respected members such as the Council of Elders
Long-term monitoring and feedback of substance use
Responsible serving of alcohol training
Improved identification and communication of problematic drinking customers and response strategy
Formalising or clarifying alcohol/tobacco sale policy
License restrictions such as time-based curfews or restrictions on amount sold
Limiting purchasing locations (reducing availability or total ban in identified hotspots)
Disconnecting Council from sales revenue
Establishing a specialised AoD service (Counselling, rehab, Alcoholics Anonymous)
Safety and security audits with the intentions to identify risks and initiating a response
Public transport options (additional taxi, lit walking paths)
School education program, targeting social perception of drug use, long-term effects of drug use and other components
Community education on the impact of Alcohol and other drug use, parental supply, and recognition of the problem. Ideally led by Council of Elders
Random Breath Testing (targeting alcohol and drug use) at roadside and workplace testing (especially heavy equipment work)
Greater police presence in the community (spot checks, regular routes, sporting clubs, and police involvement in public education)
Increase in the enforcement of law (less warnings) and harsher drug-related crime consequences (jail term)
Greater focus on reducing drug importation
Media campaigns describing the project and project goals
Culturally relevant local media advertisements on impact of alcohol and other drug use, led by individuals with lived experience
Tax increases on alcoholic drinks and/or cigarettes
Employ individuals with lived experience into healthcare or education roles
Increase public relations with services – targeting stigma
Employ additional counsellors (males)
Health workers and treatment locations dedicated to alcohol or other drug use
Free remote alcohol and other drug counselling (telephone/web/apps) and/or confidential treatment options
Upskilling health workers to increase alcohol and other drug knowledge
Involving parents in school alcohol and other drug education (eg Strengthening Families Program)
Educating parents on issues with parental supply and taking responsibility for child’s substance use
Workplace presentations and education sessions targeting work safety
Workplace policies and abstinence incentives (enforcing or encouraging no alcohol or drug use at work)
